DataElement.preferredDefinition: Category to represent the size in millimeters of the largest remaining nodule of ovarian carcinoma. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Measurement of the amount of residual disease remaining.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Remaining or left behind.:A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredDefinition: The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

Concepts.definition: The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms. --2002_Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made._Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Maximum diameter of largest remaining nodule more than 20 mm in size

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Maximum diameter of largest remaining nodule more than 20 mm in size
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status.: A natural number greater than nineteen and less than twenty-one and the quantity that it denotes.: A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

Concepts.definition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A natural number greater than nineteen and less than twenty-one and the quantity that it denotes.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/05/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The smallest natural number and quantity it denotes: a single entity, unit, or object.: Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.: A natural number greater than 9 and less than 11 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of nine and one.: A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

Concepts.definition: The smallest natural number and quantity it denotes: a single entity, unit, or object.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
A natural number greater than 9 and less than 11 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of nine and one.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/05/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms. --2002:Cancer cells that remain after attempts to remove the cancer have been made.:Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms.
Tumor cells that remain in the body following cancer treatment.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
